reviewText: I just saw "Breaking Dawn" part 1, and I was VERY impressed, even if as a man I am probably not the most typical fan of "Twilight" series. I rather liked all the "Twilight" movies until now and this one is, to my personnal taste, as good as the previous ones - and even in one aspect a little bit better, as Edward and Bella finally become lovers. Below, you will find a short description of what I believe are the best elements of this film, with very limited SPOILERS:1. Actors. All actors evolved as the serie continued and I believe they all got better with time. Robert Pattinson and Taylor Lautner are both excellent, but - in my humble opinion - it is Kristen Stewart who in this movie shines the most. Quite a lot of people frequently criticized her actorship claiming that she simply can not play at all and has a very limited assortment of expressions in her tool box. But for me, after reading "Twilight" books, this is how the character of Bella should be. I can hardly picture her wide smiling with all her teeth bared or doing any other highly extraverted things like that. In fact I believe that either by design or by accident Kristen Stewart got the things right about this character - her minimalistic approach to facial expressions actually makes (for me) Bella very believable and also quite likeable. In this part of the story, Bella takes a more dynamic approach to life by taking her destiny firmly under control. She makes important decisions and takes extreme risks, stubbornly resisting the opposite advice of all her family and friends - all of that in a deceptively unassuming way... And Kristen Stewart acted in the movie exactly as I pictured Bella did it, when I read the books. A very good job!Other actors are also great, with Ashley Greene and Billy Burke being as usual the pillars - but amongst the supporting roles it is Nikki Reed who really gets the most praise from me. She has a much bigger role in this film and she is perfect in it! The one (little) disappointment is Jackson Rathbone, who changed comletely his haircut for this film and as a result his character, Jasper, seems much less impressive, which is a pity. He also seems to appear very little in the "first line", almost as if the director preferred to hide him a little...2. Visual aspects. As usual, the images of state of Washington are great, but the tropical island where Bella and Edward spend their honey moon is also very pleasantly showed. Dark forests filled with (were)wolves are very much present here and they are a great background for the story.3. Music. As usual in those series, music and songs have been selected very carefully and with a great taste.4. The (were)wolf pack. The Quileute wolves are shown here even more and better than in the previous part. The scene of their war council, when they are all in the werewolf form, is absolutely great! The scene when Sam (the alpha male) asserts and confirms his power over the pack is excellent - as good as the description of Jacob's defiance and its consequences.5. The wedding. A very nice and moving scene with some humour elements, especially when the guests make speeches offering toasts. Emmett, Jessica and Bella's father give here a great show. In the same time Mike Newton obsesses on vampire bridesmaids from the Denali clan, to the point of drooling (and I TOTALLY understand him!). Bella's mum and, suprprise surprise, Rosalie (!) are also real treasures in wedding scenes.6. Quileute wolves vs. Cullen coven confrontation. This heartbreaking, tense and at moments violent conflict in which both sides are trapped against their will is a great moment in the Twilight saga - and its final resolution is even better! Finally it is true what the Beatles were singing - all you need is love! Babies help too...7. The fight for Bella's life, Renesmee's bloody birth and Bella's fate - excellent! Those were moments very difficult to film - but the challenge was met succesfully! Nothing more about it to avoid more spoilers, but I was very impressed!Conclusion: it is an excellent movie which I watched with great pleasure. My wife, who usually is a much harder person to please, loved it too and she is going to see it again with some girlfriends. And we will certainly both wait with great expectations for the "Breaking dawn" part 2. If it was done as well as that one, it will be certainly worth waiting one year to see it...
summary: A very tasty story about love and death dancing with wolves, mixing happiness and sadness, despair and hope - and sex and blood!

reviewText: The Twilight Saga movies as well as the books are my favorites!  Stephenie Meyer, the author of the books, is a very inspired author with a fabulous imagination.  Her books have the classic impossible romance of a teen-aged girl in love with the impossibly handsome vampire; the actors chosen to portray these characters are very beievable, and these are very popular movies with a built-in cult fan base of all those readers who loved the books and want to see their imagination fulfilled.  In this 4th installment of the movies based on the books, we have the long-awaited beautiful wedding of Edward Cullen and his love, Bella Swan, then there's the third person in the triangle, Jacob, the Indian/werewolf/shape shifter also in love with Bella.  There's the rest of the Cullen family who are just as amazing, then there's Bella's father, the inimitable Chief of Police of the authentic town of Forks, Washington, who lends a comic touch in giving a toast to the groom reminding him that he "can shoot a gun and can follow him to the ends of the earth because he's a cop"!  Then there's the honeymoon location (a surprise to Bella) on a deserted island named "Isle Esme" (a gift to Edward's "mother" Esme from her handsome vampire husband, Doctor Carlisle Cullen).  With Edward's strength, the honeymoon bed is wrecked and Bella awakens the next morning with pillow feathers floating about.  They, unbelievably conceive a child (unheard-of among a vampire married to a human) and go back home to Washington for the difficult pregnancy. A must for anyone who's read the series or is interested in the popular vampire phenomenon.  I, of course, can't wait until the final movie comes out in November, 1 year after Part 1, which I will also buy from my favorite website, Amazon.com, when it's released.

reviewText: I don't understand why so many critics hate this movie. Obviously they are not fans of the book. And, admittedly, the books are so terribly written, it's mind-numbing. But I love vampires and I have totally been drawn in by this story. The "Breaking Dawn" novel is my favorite installment in Stephenie Meyer's series, especially the first half of the book, which is what this film covers. And it's AWESOME! The lamest aspect of the film is the scene where the CGI wolves are all "talking to each other" in the woods. Very stupid. But the rest of the movie is great! Some people are saying that the film drags, but the first part of the book is really character-focused on Bella and Edward. There's no external drama for a change, except for the pissed off pack of wolves. And it's wonderful! Yes, I do wish the movie had been as graphic as the book. There should have been more sex and violence. But basically, this movie is ALL ABOUT sex and violence. What's not to love?! My understanding is that the producers needed to tone down a bunch of the graphic sex and, um, birth scenes so as to avoid an NC-17 rating or an R rating. (Hey, maybe they'll release the original cut on a special collectible DVD!) Anyway, I thoroughly enjoyed this film. Except for maybe the first one, it's definitely my fave in the series so far. I can't wait for Part II!

reviewText: The art director in this film deserves some love for creating some very cool houses.  The house owned by Dr. Carlisle and his vampire brood is to die for.  Also when Edward and Belle go to an island off the coast of Rio de Janeiro for their honeymoon, their rented beach house is terribly romantic.  But who knew that when vampires make love they destroy their bedrooms.  This must get expensive if you have any sort of love life.Anyway, after much angst, Edward and Belle do get married but while on their honeymoon, she gets pregnant.  This is evidently a big surprise to all concerned.  A little research would have suggested it was possible so maybe some vamp size condoms would have been appropriate.  We also learn that vampire/human babies grow very rapidly and very aggressively.  After a short gestation period, Belle appears to be doomed if she goes ahead delivering the baby she definitely wants.  She can't be talked out of it.Jacob enters the picture again as the uncomfortable 3rd wheel, refusing to go away even after Belle is married and preggers.  Most of the movie is the usual moody, sullen, gloomy looks given to each other.  I've seen better acting on those Mexican soap operas.  I was hoping at least for the spawn to be some horrendous monster configuration but nope, she is the most adorable baby you've ever seen...and seems to have made an imprint on the jilted Jacob.  Now that sounds interesting.  Will Belle live?  I don't know, but I do know the final chapter of the series is due in the fall of 2012.The version of this movie I had was a Blu ray but for whatever reason only had the 5.1 Dolby Digital soundtrack.  Other versions should include a DTS HD Master Audio 7.1.  The picture is excellent and is presented in a 2.40:1 aspect ratio.

reviewText: I was a bit apprehensive when it came to seeing this movie. I never read past book number 3 due to Bella's incessant whining, so the idea of seeing this movie was hovering somewhere at the bottom of my to-do list.To my relief I enjoyed this film, it was surprisingly funny and the intensity of some of the scenes had you staring slack jawed at the screen. Too many writers and directors assume that the audience is made up of diehard fans and skip too many vital parts, glad to see that this time was different. Well, if parts were skipped that is fine, because what I saw worked.Having not read the book, I had no idea what to expect in this show. Not sure how much to reveal here since any plot points will be a movie giveaway, all I can say is that the special effects people are geniuses. The visuals that they were able to accomplish are stunning and to my utter amazement, the flow was steady and at no time did I check my watch to see how much longer I had to sit there.The end, well, that was perfect. Just enough to make you anticipate the next and final installment of the Twilight series.

reviewText: I wish that Catherine Hardwicke had directed "Breaking Dawn". "Twilight" was wonderful! It was very character driven.  The director made the most of the scenery, the music and the actor's nuances and abilities. "Breaking Dawn" was disappointing. I would have loved to have seen more Edward and Bella honeymoon moments.The wedding was lovely.  However the speeches (with the exception of Edward's, which was perfect!) were far too short.  In the book, Bella says that Renee and Esme got along like a house-on-fire.  There was none of this in the movie.  It would have been nice to see the two Mums helping Bella chose her wedding gown, the flowers etc.From the trailer, you're lead to believe that Edward and Bella spend some time dancing with the locals in Rio.  In reality they only spent approx. 5 seconds kissing in front of the locals.  It would have been lovely to see a lingering Bella/Edward street dancing scene very much in the style of the school ball finale in "Twilight".I liked the honeymoon.  However it needed to have more Edward and Bella walking along the beach, swimming in the moonlight, cuddling on the bed etc. Robert Pattinson has a beautiful smile.  His whole face lights up.  We needed to see more of it.  Robert also has very expressive eyes.  The film needed more of the Bella/Edward tender looks and touches.  A female director understands the romantic things that ladies love and want to see.There should have alot more Edward supporting Bella during her difficult pregnancy.  One of the best parts of the whole movie is when Jacob accidentally sees Bella and Edward on the couch in an inimate moment - enjoying and delighting in the miracle that they've created.Catherine Hardwicke did such a wonderful job directing "Twilight".  It's still my favourite movie out of all four.  I just wish and would LOVE to see what she would have done with "Breaking Dawn".  It could have been so very much better.

reviewText: Seldom do I see movies that are profoundly, intrinsically reprehensible. Breaking Dawn was one of those movies. It's the sort of film that would-be abusers and pedophiles probably dream of; and so tedious that it will put the rest of us to sleep.This movie consists of three main events: a wedding, a honeymoon, and a pregnancy/birth. All of these are a thin veil for the true point of this film: that the noblest and rightest course of action a woman can take is to be cut open and bleed out for the sake of a fetus that every expert she's consulted predicts will die anyway. There is a lot of blood, gore and horror - but that's the "romantic" part. Somewhere, lost deep in this quagmire, are a few doomed attempts at excitement, but these are fleeting and inconsequential.I will discuss in more detail the movie as a whole, but first, what makes it truly appalling: the spousal abuse, irrational pro-fetus and anti-woman message, and pedophilic overtones. (spoilers below)First...the pro-woman-dying message (which consumes the entire latter part of the movie: the pregnancy/birth. I say "pro-woman-dying" because to call this pro-life is as hideous a travesty as calling Dr. Mengele "pro-life". This is not a story of a woman who finds herself pregnant and "chooses life"; this is the story of a woman who finds herself pregnant, is told by experts (a doctor, and both a human and vampire woman with supernatural sight) that the baby and she will die, and, even as she is starving nigh unto death, persists in this doomed pregnancy. As an emergency delivery is necessitated, she is the one who demands that they cut her open before the pain killer has kicked in because "he's suffocating!"; she is the one who gives the order for her stomach to be cut open and the infant removed, while she bleeds out on the table. Naturally, in this twisted fantasy, the baby *doesn't* die - and, although the skeletal Bella looks like she could be something out of Dr. Mengele's operating room as she bleeds out on the table, never fear. You see, being starved, having her ribs broken, and being gutted was only the prelude to an eternity of happily ever after - just as the doctor and the other people who had any way of knowing were wrong about the infant, they're wrong about her too: she is revived, lovelier and more alive than ever before. The effects of starvation are gone, the wounds are healed; and, on top of it all, she is now immortal. Choosing a gory, horrid death for yourself because you carry a zygote, you see, is really just the key to making all of your dreams come true.Secondly...spousal abuse. Bella wakes up after her wedding night to find their room torn to pieces and herself covered in bruises because, dontcha know, Edward "can't control" himself with her. She, of course, delighted in this encounter, and spends what seemed like an eternity chasing Edward (now remorseful, and swearing not to touch her) around their honeymoon island, begging for him to do it again. As with the first point, this is yet another appallingly backwards, misogynistic message for young people (this movie's target audience). Bella is only brutalized because he loves her so much; she loves it, begs for more, and gets it. So, don't worry girls...those bruises are a token of affection, and those hangups where you need to beg and beg and beg for intimacy are really your fault - because you do this to him!Finally...pedophilia. Jacob has, throughout the series, been an interesting cross of inflated ego and lack of testicular fortitude. Now, add to that illustrious resume, pedophile; because, maybe fifteen minutes after she's cut out of her non-sedated mother, Jacob comes in and "imprints on" Bella's newborn. If that sounds dirty, there's good cause; because (as was clearly stated earlier in the movie, for those fangirls who will try to delude themselves otherwise) he's marking her as his future mate - something that she has no control over, but will be forced to "be happy" with. Don't worry, though...Papa Edward does what any father would do, and radiates pride as he declares that his wife's ex has just "imprinted on" their fifteen minute old baby. Some people are naturals at parenting, right?These are the lowlights of this appalling waste of time. The full chronology of the movie goes something like this:Bella whines and pouts about having to wear a dress and heels to her wedding.Edward reveals his "rebel" past, and vampires everywhere die of laughter.Bella has a nasty nightmare about her and Edward killing everyone at their wedding.Bella sulks through her wedding.Bella forces Edward to abuse her on their wedding night.Bella chases Edward around the island, for a long time, begging him to do it again.Bella ends up crying because of Edward's rejection; Edward finally gives in.Bella realizes she's pregnant; the big bad wolves (Jacob's pack) aren't happy.Bella almost starves to death; Jacob rebels against the wolves, and swears to protect Bella.Bella gets cut open and bleeds to death.Jacob imprints on the infant; the nasty wolves go home.Everyone is happy. Hooray.I cannot emphasize enough what utter trash this movie is. The first three were enjoyable; this is complete tripe. The author's perverse fundamentalism overshadows everything else, and this becomes not a silly romance, but an appalling piece of misogynist propaganda. Save your time and money; if you're really desperate, find some drying paint to watch. That will be more entertaining, and less offensive.

reviewText: Twilight Saga Breaking Dawn pt. 2 is the final installment in the Twilight series, adapted from Stephenie Meyer's novels. This dramatic ending concludes the tale of Bella and Edward on their journey, defying the odds of love. I have never really been a fan of the Twilight series, never read any of the books or waited in line at the midnight premieres. I'm not a huge fan of dairy products, and this series contains an awful lot of cheese. But food jokes aside, I didn't completely dislike this film. Don't get me wrong there were definitely some parts that were way too dramatic, but overall I would say this is by far the best film in the Twilight Saga.The cinematography and special effects weren't anything different from the previous films, so I think they were pretty well done. However, I was very confused when I saw Renesmee. I couldn't tell if she was real or not because she looked so computer edited. I also have a problem with Bella's makeup in the opening scene. This movie picks up right where it left off and in the last film, the final scene is Bella lying on the table after she gives birth. When this movie starts, it is Bella waking up on the table two days after the birth of her daughter. But her makeup and hair are perfect. If she had been unconscious for two days how would she have on spotless makeup? Another detail that I noticed that didn't seem right was Edward and Bella's new home. Who made it? And who could design, build and furnish an entire home in only two days? I pretty sure vampires don't have super-human-carpenter powers. One last visual detail that was weird for me was Renesmee's room. When you first see it, it's a nursery, but then a day or two later it's completely different and completely refurbished. How on earth do the Collins afford to refurbish their homes every week?!I can't say I have a favorite character because the acting done by each character is a little far-fetched. I understand that the story line itself is far from realistic, but I feel like all of the actors over-played their roles. I do have a favorite scene though. The final battle scene completely shocked me, and made me actually enjoy the movie. I haven't read the books so I had no idea what to expect, but I got completely sucked into it. I watched this film with my friend who isn't a Twilight fan either, but she and I were squealing in shock during the ending scene. After the movie I felt like such a nerd because I got so into the film, but in all honesty I actually enjoyed it. No, I will not become a Twi-hard fan now, but I do have a lot more respect for this series now. And I'm thinking about reading the books.This film is the most violent and sexual out of the whole series so I recommend it for ages 13 and up. Obviously if you're a huge Twilight fanatic, you're going to see this movie no matter what anybody else tells you. And if you completely despise the movies (which I'm sure some of you probably do) you're not going to see the film no matter what your told. But if you're in the neutral category of loving/hating Twilight like I am, give it a shot and you might actually be surprised. Overall I give Twilight Saga Breaking Dawn pt. 2 four out of five stars because it definitely surpassed my expectations. Raven D, KIDS FIRST! Film Critic.Video review available at kidsfirst dot org

reviewText: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn, Part I continues the trend of a series of films that have successfully attracted a popular following for fans and upcoming fans alike.  And when comparisons arise within most recent times, one major film box office competitor comes to mind, the Harry Potter series that concluded its run with a two-part climax.  Breaking Dawn does quite the same with Part I with the three major actors Robert Pattinson (Edward Cullen), Kristen Stewart (Bella Swan), and Taylor Lautner (Jacob Black) reprising their roles as vampire, mortal, and wolf; with the last three films that showed the spurts, growth, and ups and downs of their friendship, there appears to be much growth that showed within the fourth film of how that friendship was tested.For the most part, the film begins with preparations made for Edward and Bella's wedding.  And no different from a wedding between two mortals, there also appears to be the so-called cold feet and anxiety, especially between vampire and mortal.  However, it is Bella's premonitions and nightmares that clearly show her anxieties.  But as viewers will see, there is a difference between nightmares and reality.  As the film proceeds, the never ending tensions between Edward and Jacob are evident, and outside the circle of friendship between Edward, Jacob, and Bella that is depicted within the film, one may think that the film may progress within the same lines as the last two films - the intense emotions of jealously and rivalry.  But in Breaking Dawn, one may see the maturity that develops especially between Edward and Jacob that derives from exterior tensions and rivalries outside their circle but between their respective families of vampires and wolves.  And what breaks the tension temporarily, the laws of nature and family history that comes in the form of the birth of a new addition.Breaking Dawn Part I has an intensity that differs from the last three films.  And like Harry Potter, fans and new fans may be impatient for the next and last installment.  But no doubt, the ending of this film may have viewers at the edge of their seat especially with last hour that ended with a suspenseful and surprised ending - it's all in the eyes.

reviewText: **1/2If you're developing cold feet at the prospect of tying the knot - especially if you happen to be human and your intended a vampire - you may want to avoid watching "The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn - Part 1," written by Melissa Rosenberg and directed by Bill Condon.  And if you are contemplating having a baby with a vampire, then you REALLY don't want to catch this fourth film based on the series of phenomenally successful novels by Stephanie Meyer.In this installment, Bella (Kristen Stewart) and her dreamy vampire boyfriend Edward (Robert Pattinson) finally get hitched, but happiness is fleeting for the newlyweds as the still-human Bella finds herself coping with the most disturbing and problematic movie pregnancy since "Rosemary's Baby" (or "Alien," if you want to count that as a pregnancy).In purely narrative terms, this is a fairly static entry in the series, as Bella wastes away to skeletal status through the ordeal, and everyone sits around discussing the moral implications of having an unprecedented cross-species child, especially when the birth experience itself will likely spell death for the mother.  There's a halfhearted attempt at revving up the action when the werewolves threaten to intervene by killing Bella, but the star-crossed and loyalty-divided Jacob (Taylor Lautner) defuses the situation in quick order (it also leads to a ludicrous voiceover conversation among the wolves that provides some unintentional laughs for the audience).Still, Stewart gets to do more intense acting than she has thus far in the series, and Bella's transformation plus the addition of the child offer new story possibilities for "Breaking Dawn - Part 2," due for release in November 2012.

reviewText: I wanted to see this movie so much that I watched all the specials about it while I was on vacation and went to the midnight release of the film. I've never wanted to see ANY film enough to go to a movie theater that late at night, but I wanted to see if it would live up to its hype (and the book). "The Twilight Saga: New Moon (Single-Disc Edition)" the movie and "New Moon (The Twilight Saga)" book are still my favorites out of this series, but "Breaking Dawn" was pretty good. There were some weak moments though.Cons: When I first saw "Twilight (Two-Disc Special Edition)" I thought, "The action in this film leaves much to be desired." I felt the same way about this film. The directors for "New Moon" and "The Twilight Saga: Eclipse (Two-Disc Special Edition)" made the vampires' movement much easier to believe. Like "Twilight," the action in this film was a bit clumsy and even too unrealistic for a vampire movie. Watching the scene with Jasper and Emmett hopping up and down in the window before the "bachelor party" are prime examples of how the film got a little goofy when it could've been much better. In "Breaking Dawn," they looked like they were jumping on trampolines and it was really lame. After the directors/producers already saw the right way of vampire movement, I don't understand why they reverted back to the amateur way of doing it. The extra dance twirls with Taylor and Kristen were a bit much, too. Once was enough. The rest reminded me of that awkward love scene in "Abduction."Pros: Unlike many women, I don't ooh and aww when I see a wedding dress, but even I had to applaud the dress that was picked for Bella. It was beautiful. My mouth dropped open when I saw the dress and Kristin Stewart looked amazing in it. I think Kristin got to show some more versatility in this film. I liked her comedic scenes when trying to coax Edward into having sex again after a very "busy" bedroom experience. I did not enjoy "Breaking Dawn" the book, but Bella's character was MUCH more likeable in the movie. I'm Team Jacob so any scene with Taylor Lautner and the rest of the wolfpack was enjoyable to me, and I really like Leah. I always wanted her to be more developed in the book so I'm hoping Part 2 continues to do that the way Part 1 does. Robert Pattinson was great, too, but I like the love rivalry with Jacob more. Actually the entire cast did a great job in this film like all others, and I liked the voices talking over each other with the wolves. That was the first time I saw that in action, and I thought that was a great idea considering they can all read each other's minds.That birth scene was graphic. I hid my head in my hood at one point because I was so grossed out by the chewing birth of this bloody demon baby. Ugh! This film is far more mature than the others. Can't wait to see Part 2. (I knew Part 1 was going to leave me counting down the days on my calendar again. Argh!)

reviewText: but this one really disappointed me. I enjoyed the second and third entries in this series. The first movie didn't move me much at all. But this one I found to be even worse than the first. And I genuinely didn't want to be of that opinion. I had heard negative things about this movie, but wanted to give it the benefit of my doubt; the way I do with almost everything receiving negative hype. In my experience, the negativity is almost always overstated, and things aren't as bad as people tend to be saying. Sadly, that is not the case with this film in my opinion.Firstly, I should point out that I'm normally a fan of films like this. I'm a male, but I really do enjoy a good love story. However this film felt like almost pure fluff. And the story wasn't sensible to begin with. If you had never seen another Twilight film, you would be utterly lost while watching this. Most of the CGI was obvious and overdone. Plainly put, the film focuses too much on the more trivial parts of the story, and tries too hard throughout.Part of what's wrong here is that this is where the storyline begins to break down in the arena of common sense. If you've ever been in a truly loving relationship, you're going to spend the entirety of your watching experience wondering why Bella's made the choice that she has. She loses her entire life in order to be with Edward, but doesn't seem to be any more needing of him than she is of Jacob. As an example, Jacob is called upon by Edward within the story to try and help Bella, because he has a deeper connection with Bella than Edward can understand. And had she chosen Jacob, the penalty to her reality would have been much less severe. This and many more flaws in the realism of the storyline make this hard to take to heart. It doesn't help that the scripting was terrible in most places.The argument between the wolves was almost impossible to follow; due to some very poor sound structuring. The birth scene was overly grotesque for a movie that spent half of its time focusing on a wedding and honeymoon. The vampires are no longer shimmering in this film. And...clearly, I was not pleased with a great many things about this film.If I had to point to a redeeming quality about this film, I would point to the imprint moment. And it was supremely heartfelt and moving. Again though, had I not known the storyline before watching this, I probably wouldn't have understood what I was even seeing. But do know that the imprint moment is excellent. This would have been a one star review otherwise. Even if you strip my feelings about the shoddy storyline away from this review, the direction of the film is still uninteresting and sloppy.I sincerely wanted to like this film. But I didn't. You may feel differently. And that's to be expected. But I consider it appropriate to give my honest opinion in all cases. And, in the case of this film, my opinion isn't a positive one. There are better movies to spend twenty dollars on. Even when this is a five dollar film, there will still be better movies to be had. Watch it if you must (most will still want to, and I get that). But don't say I didn't warn you that this one really is worthy of passing on.

reviewText: Love the Twilight books and I think the casting of Bella and Edward really brought the characters to life in the movie series.  Like others, I greatly anticipated the Breaking Dawn movie and their relationship moving forward.  However, I don't think this director likes vampires.  It seems to me BD takes away the fantasy (for the most part) and replaces it with just a teenage love story.  Do I love the story...sure, but the fantasy is the vampire/human relationship.  Condon takes away the make-up...no pearly white, sparkly vampires in this flick!  Also, I have to mention the hair...Almost everyone changes, Edward goes much shorter, Jasper gets a cut and color, Rosalie (Blondie) goes brunette, Carlisle...etc.  I want my vampires sparkly and beautiful, darn it!  Some of the best book material was totally overlooked, i.e., before/after cars, telling Charlie of the marriage plans, the wedding fittings, etc.  However, we get stupid toasts at the wedding for comic relief??? And an extended shot of Rio's street dancers????  If you blink, you'll miss the much anticipated wedding night...no Edward making eggs endlessly for Bella, no snuggling and movie watching.  When we get home to Forks, all our vampires (who are now extremely humanized) are busy..no statues here, and the wolves have turned into cartoon figures complete with dialogue.  The Cullen home doesn't even seem to have the allure of the previous movies.  Bella's final scenes - not in the tight ice blue dress of the book, but flowing cobalt.  Yes, I'll see the next one, but I won't anticipate it quite the same way knowing that it will pick up where this one left off and I can't help but wonder, what changes I'll notice next. The writer was a producer on this movie, but she should have stuck to her gut insticts about her characters and made sure we didn't lose her vampires (and our fantasies)at the hands of yet another director.

reviewText: I know I am not the film's target audience. Whoever the filmmakers are, they are not making the "Twilight" saga for a forty-something male, who is not a big fan of the vampire / romance genre. But when Bill Condon, director of such films as "Gods and Monsters" "Kinsey" and "Dreamgirls" is to helm "The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn," I hoped things might be a bit different. Plus, the film's photography is by Guillermo Navarro, Oscar winner for "Pan's Labyrinth."So, having watched "Part 1" of the two-part finale of the franchise, I still don't know what to say about it. Though I don't think the film is as terrible as some critics say, the film often feels like a long and slow warm-up for the next installment, which I hope will be full of action. Well, in short, I thought "The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn" was pretty boring.The film takes nearly two hours to tell us what can be told in one hour (as Amazon's editorial review has neatly summarized). Edward and Bella marry, but a human-vampire marriage is not all romantic and sweet. Not a bad story, but more hints as to what is to come, or some subtexts under the melodramatic romance would have been of great help in interesting us, fans or non-fans of the series, in the drama between the married couple.We are also given chances to see the CG werewolves fighting, but not much, and the visual quality is at best acceptable. The subplot about Jacob and his clan, which could have been more interesting than the main plot, is sidelined by the birth scene that would seem very horrid to some. Technically the film is competent, and considering the drawn-out storyline, uninspired dialogue and bland acting from some, if not all, players, Bill Condon did a pretty good job as director.
summary: A Very Long Warm-Up for the Up-Coming Part 2

reviewText: I have not read the books so I didn't know what to expect from the beginning of the end of this series. I was more disappointed in the choices the new director made rather than in the storyline. Has this director even SEEN the other movies because nothing flowed properly with this movie at all. All of a sudden the vampires can be in full sunlight and not sparkle even a little bit...why is that? There were plenty of full sun scenes and none of the vampires sparkled, not even a little body glitter...nothing.The vampires makeup looked absolutely terrible this time. Seeing it at the theater made them look very pasty and sticky like their Mom's had packed on way too much grease paint for Halloween.Their eyes...at the wedding many of the vampire guests had very freaky looking red eyes and none of the human guests noticed?? The Cullens eyes seemed to switch all the time from gold, to black to gold...no idea why. Had they forgotten their contact lenses on some days?I also wasn't happy with the overly excessive use of music and staring...lots of staring set to music, it took the place of dialogue in many scenes. I didn't like the music selections this time, either. Very dull and forgettable. The other movies used music more appropriately and there were some very memorable, haunting songs that really stuck in your head. Not this time.The funniest part of all, the wolves "talking". Not a good idea and I nearly laughed out loud when they began to "talk" in their heads while still in wolf form and they could hear each other. This fact has been alluded to in the past, but we don't need to actually hear it. It could only have been made worse if they had made the wolves' mouths move in time to the words as many kiddie animal movies do. No, this scene would have played out much better if they had all been in human form. And yes, the wolves seemed much smaller and less imposing this time.Am I the only one who is left wondering why Edward said he could finally hear the baby's thoughts and then called it a HE when the baby was clearly a SHE? Was Edward simply lying to Bella to try to give her some comfort?I watched this movie with a friend who hasn't seen a single one of these yet, and she completely hated it. She said the vampires looked ugly and she asked how they could be in the sunlight? My point exactly.No, Breaking Dawn is not my favorite movie in this series. I think it could have been alot better with a different director.Now to address the three major concerns that have some reviewers in such an uproar...which I find to be rather silly, myself.1. Bella's bruises.I don't view Bella's bruises from her honeymoon as spousal abuse. Anyone who has seen this from the beginning knows that Edward has always been afraid of hurting Bella because vampires are so strong, which is why they have never been together before. Once he saw the bruises he was horrified and did his best to avoid her. Bella pursued and seduced him because she wanted to feel human for as long as possible, not because she liked being hurt. She knew that feelings and sensations would change once she was no longer human, that's all, nothing abusive or perverse about it.2. Bella's choice to keep the baby even though it could end her own life.Bella knew that keeping their baby was her one and ONLY chance to have a child, once she became a vampire, no chance of babies. When she discovered she was pregnant against all odds...they didn't think it could happen, she chose to keep it because she hadn't realized before how much she wanted a baby.  Bella has also witnessed Rosalie's pain and anguish from never having a child of her own. So yes, Bella did risk her own life to save the baby, but she had always intended to be turned into a vampire, so she expected to be turned at the last minute of death, like the others in the Cullen family.3. Jacob imprinting on the baby.I was not offended by Jacob's imprinting on the newborn, I don't understand how anyone can view that as pedophilia. I see it as Jacob's ultimate sacrifice for Bella. He is now the protector and guardian of Renesmee. Jacob knows he can't have Bella and he refuses to love anyone else, so he chose to use his imprint to save the life of her newborn that she fought so desperately to bring into the world. That in no way means he intends to make the baby his bride. Jacob knew that if he imprinted on the baby, all the wolves would have to respect that (their ultimate law) and not kill the baby or harm her in the future. Edward was humbled and proud to announce the fact that Jacob imprinted on the baby because he knew what a great sacrifice it was for Jacob to go against his pack and save the child's life. Jacob will lead a solitary life without a mate because he chose to be the protector of Bella's baby. Jacob loves Bella, she loves Edward and the baby so Jacob saved the baby's life for Bella. That's all. Nothing pervy about it. Some people need to quit slanting things to their own sick, twisted way of thinking. And by the way...these are just fiction books and movies. They are not intended for real-life interpretations or representations...so why on Earth would anyone be so offended by a movie? No one is forcing you to watch, so don't.

reviewText: ... hot, sweet, and thoroughly mixed up.After some family weirdness, Bella arrives a new high school in mid-term. Even when she receives a warm welcome, her mood stays as dark as the grey skies over the Pacific Northwest. Soon, she meets Edward, a Steppenwolf character. He's handsome enough, but a loner and a mystery, the kind that Bella would like to solve. When she's assigned to his lab bench in science class, he nearly bolts like a spooked horse. That just tweaks her interest even more.Then an out-of-control car nearly crushes her. Edward 'pushes her out of the way,' or so she tells people. The truth is far stranger, though, and leads her to solve his mystery. That (plus the fact that he just saved her life) just commits her to him even more. Much to everyone's surprise, including his own, he reciprocates. Although Bella's father worries that he's a little old for her - if he only knew! - only a biologically driven tension really invades their happiness. Oh, and a couple of thoroughly bad badguys.Some nice moments follow, including a "meet the family" scene with more than usual awkwardness. We see some realistically poor teen judgement, too, the kind so believably motivated by an overheated romantic sense. Giving away much more of the plot would mean giving too much away, but there's some good action, fearful moments that never go too far, and charming humor at the family baseball game.This could have been a mess of a genre-hopping teen romance flick, but the pieces came together nicely. Maybe it won't be one for the ages, but it looks like one of the better date movies in a long time, especially for the teen demographic.-- wiredweird
